<td style="padding-top:20px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good morning. </strong>The CDC released new health guidance around upcoming holiday celebrations. A few points worth highlighting:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Your Power Rangers mask doesn’t substitute for a cloth mask on Halloween.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Good news: With potlucks discouraged, you won't have to suffer through Norm’s green bean casserole this year.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Invest in long underwear now. Thanksgiving dinner could be outside.</span></li>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
AUTO
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/22/tesla-rolls-plan-slash-cost-ev-batteries?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Musk Charges the Batteryfield
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Tesla battery illustration" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNDg4L3Rlc2xhX2JhdHRlcnlfaWxsdXN0cmF0aW9uLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">“It’s a little bit hard to read the room with everyone in cars.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That’s a quote from the one and only Tesla CEO Elon Reeve Musk at the company’s shareholder meeting and “Battery Day” event yesterday. Musk did his thing (touting Tesla’s manufacturing capabilities and talking cathodes) onstage for a crowd...of parked Teslas. With shareholders inside them to practice safe social distancing.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Setting the scene</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The EV battery sector is heating up like your MacBook when you have too many tabs open, and Musk teased an exciting battery announcement in the days leading up to the event. Automakers like GM are pouring resources into developing their own, while companies like China’s BYD are jockeying to offer the cheapest, most powerful option. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The company update: </strong>To paraphrase...we’re in beast mode. Musk <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/22/elon-musk-at-battery-day-tesla-deliveries-to-rise-30percent-to-40percent-in-2020.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">said</a> 2020 deliveries will rise between 30% and 40% over last year. That works out to between 477,750 and 514,500 cars.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Tesla is also working on updates to its driver-supporting software Autopilot; it will release a beta of the "full self-driving version" in the coming months. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The battery update: </strong>Musk announced next-generation batteries, the 4680, that will have 6x more power, provide 5x more energy, and increase driving range by 16%...at half the cost. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Why is that a tease-worthy announcement? Reducing battery price is key to making EVs cost-competitive with gasoline-powered cars. Tesla's helped bring battery costs down from over $600/kWh to about $150/kWh...but it needs to land at around $100/kWh to achieve what you could call "petroleum parity," </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/teslas-battery-day-why-elon-musk-and-other-car-makers-are-fighting-over-batteries-11600772401?mod=business_lead_pos2&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">writes the WSJ</a></span><span>.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Musk said the goal was to make a $25,000 EV...that’s also “fully autonomous” in three years. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking</strong> <strong style="color:#000">ahead</strong>...“To be clear, it will take us about a year to 18 months to start to realize these advantages,” Musk said. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
QUOTES
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/22/top-quotes-tuesdays-news?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
On the Record
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Tuesday’s top quotes:</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">“I intend to follow the Constitution and precedent in considering the President’s nominee”</strong>—Sen. Mitt Romney <a href="https://apnews.com/1ff16388e04496039c229ea8e551b855?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">cleared the way</a> for President Trump’s Supreme Court pick to move forward with the confirmation process.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">“There are some break-glass options available”</strong>—Facebook’s Head of Global Affairs Nick Clegg told the FT the company would take <a href="https://www.ft.com/content/82ead3c3-774f-4b12-b7ed-e1c0bbf70261?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">extraordinary measures</a> to stop the flow of content if uncertainty around the election led to unrest or even violence.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">“We've reached a perilous turning point"</strong>—British Prime Minister Boris Johnson<strong style="color:#000"> </strong>introduced new <a href="https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-54250696?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">coronavirus restrictions</a> to prevent a second wave from turning into a tsunami. Pubs, bars, and restaurants will have to close at 10pm and employees are encouraged to work from home for the next six months.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">“The whole thing is a crock”</strong>—Barry Diller, media mogul and chairman of Expedia and IAC, is <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/22/barry-diller-on-tiktok-deal-the-whole-thing-is-a-crock.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">not a fan</a> of how the TikTok sale was handled. “Its original aims are out the window. It has just [become] a whole political mismash,” he told CNBC.</p> 
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">“It’s time”</strong>—Disney’s parks chief <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-disney-parks/disney-appeal-to-california-its-time-to-let-disneyland-reopen-idUSKCN26D2TH?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">pleaded</a> with California officials to allow Disneyland to open in Anaheim.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ENVIRONMENT
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/22/china-pledges-go-carbon-neutral-2060?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Let the Climate Countdown Begin
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Climate clock " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNDg3L2NsaW1hdGVfY2xvY2suanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>ClimateClock</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">On Saturday afternoon, a giant clock began counting down in NYC’s Union Square, but it wasn’t Mayor de Blasio jumping the gun on New Year’s. The <a href="https://www.cbsnews.com/news/climate-change-clock-new-york-city-time-remaining-global-deadline/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Climate Clock</a> shows how long humans have, based on current emissions rates, before depleting Earth’s “carbon budget” and sending temperatures rising past the critical 1.5℃ threshold.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The activists who installed it aren’t the only ones worried about a ticking time bomb. At yesterday’s virtual UN General Assembly, China pledged to go <a href="https://apnews.com/7a4216ad4026090adb8d600fab210406?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">carbon neutral</a> by 2060. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>President Xi Jinping wants emissions to peak before the decade’s up. However, as the world’s biggest polluter, China will have to drastically cut emissions to reach net-zero.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">On the corporate side…</strong>big names including Walmart, Morgan Stanley, Google, and Amazon have made big sustainability promises ahead of Climate Week NYC this week. Compared to years past, these promises look less like marketing pamphlets and more like to-do lists, <a href="https://www.axios.com/corporate-sustainability-pledges-climate-64b3a673-8619-4dd3-944a-476b784b55f5.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Axios’s Ben Geman</a> writes. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">BP, for example, is pledging to significantly cut oil production in the next 10 years as part of its broader shift away from fossil fuels. And Walmart is planning to zero out operational emissions without buying carbon offsets.</p>

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
PUBLIC HEALTH
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/22/airlines-call-global-antigen-testing-passengers?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">

</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Fearing mandatory quarantine policies are keeping travelers from breaking out their neck pillows, the International Air Transport Association called for a universal <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/22/airlines-call-for-covid-19-tests-before-all-international-flights.html?__source=twitter%7Cmain&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">antigen testing requirement</a> for international passengers yesterday. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><a href="https://www.vox.com/2020/8/27/21374002/rapid-covid-19-test-3m-abbott?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Antigen tests</a> are diagnostic tools that look for proteins made by Covid-19. Within 15 minutes and for as little as $10, they can detect if someone is infected. Don’t confuse them with <em>antibody</em> tests, which check whether your immune system has already beaten the virus. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Antigen testing is less reliable than lab-based diagnostics, but airlines, cruise lines, and event operators are hoping the cheap, fast, and easily deployable tests can unlock the pandemic-stricken economy. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Case study: </strong></span><span>Over Labor Day weekend at the Utopia music festival in the Poconos, 200+ people were </span><span><a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-09-21/music-festivals-create-testing-bubbles-to-get-partiers-back-out?sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">screened</a></span><span> before entering. Six were turned away, but organizers say the event was otherwise successful at creating a “bubble.” </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>As antigen tests become more widely available, they could make it easier for people to get tested more regularly (or even test themselves at home). Frequent and rapid results could help schools, sports stadiums, offices, and clubs welcome guests back safely.</p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GAMING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/22/sega-nintendos-console-war-brief-history?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Choose Your Fighter: Sega vs. Nintendo
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="SEGA fighters" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=508 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/eoMo9D7JKAxyU9B6OU/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="SEGA fighters" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/eoMo9D7JKAxyU9B6OU/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Xbox vs. PlayStation rivalry will be in full force this fall. But long before siblings fought over Microsoft or Sony, the console wars were waged between Nintendo and Sega. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Today, CBS All Access’s first <a href="https://www.cbs.com/movies/console-wars-trailer/trailer/A2AEA715-A31D-320F-5FE2-7097EE823FC7/?gclsrc=aw.ds&&ref=__iv_p_1_g_110420577313_w_kwd-952729166283_h_9067609_ii__d_c_v__n_g_c_464265960637_l__t__e__r__vi__&ftag=PPM-20-10aac4h&vndid=google%24null%24null%24%2Bconsole%20%2Bwars%20%2Bcbs&gclid=EAIaIQobChMI_pPS26b96wIVB7bICh2bBQlfEAAYASAAEgK65PD_BwE&gclsrc=aw.ds&_ivgu=d5ea52a9-dde8-4511-bf68-f3fba22fb660&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">feature-length documentary</a>, <em>Console Wars</em>, spills all the <a href="https://www.cinemablend.com/news/2554988/console-wars-quick-things-to-know-about-the-nintendo-and-sega-feud-before-the-cbs-all-access-documentary?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">’90s corporate tea</a> (Espionage! Intrigue!). Let's take a quick hop down memory lane.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Sega declares a war for thumbs</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Nintendo was the gaming industry’s Regina George until Sega rolled into gamers’ hearts at the turn of the ‘90s with Sonic the Hedgehog, the Genesis console, and an ad campaign that boasted its 16-bit graphic supremacy: “<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k7nsBoqJ6s8&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Genesis Does What Nintendon't</a>”.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">When Nintendo and Sega both released <em>Mortal Kombat </em>in 1993, Nintendo swapped sweat for blood. Both versions of that game set off criticism that videogames inspire real-world violence and sent both companies to court. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The companies spent two years in front of congressional committees belittling each other’s tech, but it did result in the creation of a game-rating entity. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Sega put up a good fight, but Nintendo landed the K.O. in 1996 with the N64 console. The same year, the CEO of Sega of America stepped down, and by 2002, the company gave up on consoles altogether to focus on making games.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">For more, catch the documentary or <a href="https://bookshop.org/books/console-wars-sega-nintendo-and-the-battle-that-defined-a-generation/9780062276704?aid=565&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">read the acclaimed book</a> by Blake Harris. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bonus trivia:</strong> Was Sonic or Mario the first videogame character to have a balloon in the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade? Answer's at the bottom of the newsletter. </p>

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FITNESS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/22/equinox-opens-fully-outdoor-gym-los-angeles?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Need to Squeeze Some Reps Between Pitch Meetings?
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Outdoor Equinox gym" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNDg1L291dGRvb3JfZXF1aW5veF9neW0uanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Equinox</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That’s upscale fitness club Equinox’s new fully outdoor gym in Century City, LA, which <a href="https://hauteliving.com/2020/09/equinox-opens-first-fully-outdoor-gym-los-angeles/690420/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">opened Monday</a>. It sprawls across 27,000 square feet and features all the typical Equinox stuff: treadmills, weights, lockers, and the absolute most attractive person you’ve ever seen in your life doing squats. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Covid-19 dropped a barbell on the IRL fitness industry, and the allure of Kiehl’s moisturizers might not be enough to keep Equinox afloat. The rooftop gym, called Equinox+ In The Wild, is an attempt to find a solution. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The gym is only temporary, though, and only viable in places like LA, where seasons haven’t been invented yet. </p>

Steve Mnuchin agreed that the economy was rebounding, but more government aid will be needed to make sure the recovery doesn't stall. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHousing: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eU.S. home sales hit a nearly \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-economy-housing/u-s-existing-home-sales-near-14-year-high-prices-race-to-record-peak-idUSKCN26D1Z9?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e14-year high\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e in August. A huge problem for the housing market right now is a lack of supply.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso ]\u003e\u003c! -- --\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- \u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003c!-- END MARKETS --\u003e\n\u003c!-- ARTICLE ---\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso ]\u003e\u003c! -- --\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"c6 \" style=\"margin-bottom:7px\"\u003e\n\u003c!-- \u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003cth class=\"card\" style=\"text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px\"\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding: 15px;\"\u003e\n\u003ch3 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nAUTO \n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/22/tesla-rolls-plan-slash-cost-ev-batteries?email={{profile.email}}\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nMusk Charges the Batteryfield\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Tesla battery illustration\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNDg4L3Rlc2xhX2JhdHRlcnlfaWxsdXN0cmF0aW9uLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e“It’s a little bit hard to read the room with everyone in cars.”\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThat’s a quote from the one and only Tesla CEO Elon Reeve Musk at the company’s shareholder meeting and “Battery Day” event yesterday. Musk did his thing (touting Tesla’s manufacturing capabilities and talking cathodes) onstage for a crowd...of parked Teslas. With shareholders inside them to practice safe social distancing.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eSetting the scene\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe EV battery sector is heating up like your MacBook when you have too many tabs open, and Musk teased an exciting battery announcement in the days leading up to the event. Automakers like GM are pouring resources into developing their own, while companies like China’s BYD are jockeying to offer the cheapest, most powerful option. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe company update: \u003c/strong\u003eTo paraphrase...we’re in beast mode. Musk \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/22/elon-musk-at-battery-day-tesla-deliveries-to-rise-30percent-to-40percent-in-2020.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esaid\u003c/a\u003e 2020 deliveries will rise between 30% and 40% over last year. That works out to between 477,750 and 514,500 cars.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eTesla is also working on updates to its driver-supporting software Autopilot; it will release a beta of the \"full self-driving version\" in the coming months. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe battery update: \u003c/strong\u003eMusk announced next-generation batteries, the 4680, that will have 6x more power, provide 5x more energy, and increase driving range by 16%...at half the cost. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eWhy is that a tease-worthy announcement? Reducing battery price is key to making EVs cost-competitive with gasoline-powered cars. Tesla's helped bring battery costs down from over $600/kWh to about $150/kWh...but it needs to land at around $100/kWh to achieve what you could call \"petroleum parity,\" \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/teslas-battery-day-why-elon-musk-and-other-car-makers-are-fighting-over-batteries-11600772401?mod=business_lead_pos2\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewrites the WSJ\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eMusk said the goal was to make a $25,000 EV...that’s also “fully autonomous” in three years. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking\u003c/strong\u003e \u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eahead\u003c/strong\u003e...“To be clear, it will take us about a year to 18 months to start to realize these Pubs, bars, and restaurants will have to close at 10pm and employees are encouraged to work from home for the next six months.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e“The whole thing is a crock”\u003c/strong\u003e—Barry Diller, media mogul and chairman of Expedia and IAC, is \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/22/barry-diller-on-tiktok-deal-the-whole-thing-is-a-crock.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enot a fan\u003c/a\u003e of how the TikTok sale was handled. “Its original aims are out the window. width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOn Saturday afternoon, a giant clock began counting down in NYC’s Union Square, but it wasn’t Mayor de Blasio jumping the gun on New Year’s. The \u003ca href=\"https://www.cbsnews.com/news/climate-change-clock-new-york-city-time-remaining-global-deadline/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eClimate Clock\u003c/a\u003e shows how long humans have, based on current emissions rates, before depleting Earth’s “carbon budget” and sending temperatures rising past the critical 1.5℃ threshold.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe activists who installed it aren’t the only ones worried about a ticking time bomb. At yesterday’s virtual UN General Assembly, China pledged to go \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/7a4216ad4026090adb8d600fab210406?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecarbon neutral\u003c/a\u003e by 2060. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003ePresident Xi Jinping wants emissions to peak before the decade’s up. However, as the world’s biggest polluter, China will have to drastically cut emissions to reach net-zero.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eOn the corporate side…\u003c/strong\u003ebig names including Walmart, Morgan Stanley, Google, and Amazon have made big sustainability promises ahead of Climate Week NYC this week. Compared to years past, these promises look less like marketing pamphlets and more like to-do lists, \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/corporate-sustainability-pledges-climate-64b3a673-8619-4dd3-944a-476b784b55f5.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eAxios’s Ben Geman\u003c/a\u003e writes. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBP, for example, is pledging to significantly cut oil production in the next 10 years as part of its broader shift away from fossil fuels. And Walmart is planning to zero out operational emissions without buying carbon offsets.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nAirlines Ask for Covid Pop Quizzes\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFearing mandatory quarantine policies are keeping travelers from breaking out their neck pillows, the International Air Transport Association called for a universal \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/22/airlines-call-for-covid-19-tests-before-all-international-flights.html?__source=twitter%7Cmain\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eantigen testing requirement\u003c/a\u003e for international passengers yesterday. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.vox.com/2020/8/27/21374002/rapid-covid-19-test-3m-abbott?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eAntigen tests\u003c/a\u003e are diagnostic tools that look for proteins made by Covid-19. Within 15 minutes and for as little as $10, they can detect if someone is infected. Don’t confuse them with \u003cem\u003eantibody\u003c/em\u003e tests, which check whether your immune system has already beaten the virus. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAntigen testing is less reliable than lab-based diagnostics, but airlines, cruise lines, and event operators are hoping the cheap, fast, and easily deployable tests can unlock the pandemic-stricken economy. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eCase study: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eOver Labor Day weekend at the Utopia music festival in the Poconos, 200+ people were \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-09-21/music-festivals-create-testing-bubbles-to-get-partiers-back-out?sref=KkPzpZvz\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003escreened\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e before entering. Six were turned away, but organizers say the event was otherwise successful at creating a “bubble.” \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eAs antigen tests become more widely available, they could make it easier for people to get tested more regularly (or even test themselves at home). Frequent and rapid results could help schools, sports stadiums, offices, and clubs welcome guests back safely.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nChoose Your Fighter: Sega vs. Nintendo\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c!--[if mso]\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"SEGA fighters\" style=\"display: block; src=\"https://media.giphy.com/media/eoMo9D7JKAxyU9B6OU/giphy.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c!--\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eGiphy\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe Xbox vs. PlayStation rivalry will be in full force this fall. But long before siblings fought over Microsoft or Sony, the console wars were waged between Nintendo and Sega. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eToday, CBS All Access’s first \u003ca href=\"https://www.cbs.com/movies/console-wars-trailer/trailer/A2AEA715-A31D-320F-5FE2-7097EE823FC7/?gclsrc=aw.ds\u0026\u0026ref=__iv_p_1_g_110420577313_w_kwd-952729166283_h_9067609_ii__d_c_v__n_g_c_464265960637_l__t__e__r__vi__\u0026ftag=PPM-20-10aac4h\u0026vndid=google%24null%24null%24%2Bconsole%20%2Bwars%20%2Bcbs\u0026gclid=EAIaIQobChMI_pPS26b96wIVB7bICh2bBQlfEAAYASAAEgK65PD_BwE\u0026gclsrc=aw.ds\u0026_ivgu=d5ea52a9-dde8-4511-bf68-f3fba22fb660\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efeature-length documentary\u003c/a\u003e, \u003cem\u003eConsole Wars\u003c/em\u003e, spills all the \u003ca href=\"https://www.cinemablend.com/news/2554988/console-wars-quick-things-to-know-about-the-nintendo-and-sega-feud-before-the-cbs-all-access-documentary?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e’90s corporate tea\u003c/a\u003e (Espionage! Intrigue!). Let's take a quick hop down memory lane.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eSega declares a war for thumbs\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNintendo was the gaming industry’s Regina George until Sega rolled into gamers’ hearts at the turn of the ‘90s with Sonic the Hedgehog, the Genesis console, and an ad campaign that boasted its 16-bit graphic supremacy: “\u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k7nsBoqJ6s8\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eGenesis Does What Nintendon't\u003c/a\u003e”.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhen Nintendo and Sega both released \u003cem\u003eMortal Kombat \u003c/em\u003ein 1993, Nintendo swapped sweat for blood. Both versions of that game set off criticism that videogames inspire real-world violence and sent both companies to court. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe companies spent two years in front of congressional committees belittling each other’s tech, but it did result in the creation of a game-rating entity. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSega put up a good fight, but Nintendo landed the K.O. in 1996 with the N64 console. The same year, the CEO of Sega of America stepped down, and by 2002, the company gave up on consoles altogether to focus on making games.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFor more, catch the documentary or \u003ca href=\"https://bookshop.org/books/console-wars-sega-nintendo-and-the-battle-that-defined-a-generation/9780062276704?aid=565\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eread the acclaimed book\u003c/a\u003e by Blake Harris. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBonus trivia:\u003c/strong\u003e Was Sonic or Mario the first videogame character to have a balloon in the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade? Answer's at the bottom of the newsletter. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:
